content: The "Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006" cites violations of human rights and democratic principles by the Government of Belarus, particularly in flawed elections and disregard for basic freedoms. The Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006 criticizes the Belarusian government for failing to meet OSCE commitments for democratic elections, arbitrary use of state power, and widespread detentions. It highlights the regime of Aleksandr Lukashenka for maintaining power through illegal means and disregarding basic rights. The government is also accused of not making credible efforts to solve the cases of disappeared opposition figures and journalists. The Government of Belarus has failed to address the disappearances of opposition figures and journalists, imprisoned political activists, harassed pro-democratic individuals, and targeted independent media for reprisals. The Belarusian authorities have targeted independent media, suppressed freedom of speech, and harassed civil society organizations and religious communities, perpetuating a climate of fear in the country. The Belarusian authorities have imposed heavy fines, denied permission for religious services, and used threats, firings, and beatings to silence dissent. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to call for the release of political prisoners, support democracy and human rights in Belarus, and preserve the country's independence and sovereignty. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 aims to support democracy, human rights, and sovereignty in Belarus, promote democratic movements, reject flawed elections, and work with international partners for Belarus' integration into the European community of democracies. Assistance is provided to promote democracy and civil society in Belarus. Assistance is provided to promote democracy and civil society in Belarus by supporting the development of a democratic political culture and civil society. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to focus on expanding independent media, supporting civil society development, and aiding human rights defenders in Belarus. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to support civil society development, human rights defenders, democratic political parties, and transparent electoral processes. Authorization of appropriations is also updated for 2007 and 2008. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to include radio and television broadcasting to Belarus. Additionally, sanctions against the government of Belarus are addressed in Section 6. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to include sanctions against the government of Belarus until specific conditions are met, such as the release of jailed individuals based on political or religious beliefs and the withdrawal of politically motivated legal charges against opposition activists and journalists in Belarus. The conditions for sanctions against the government of Belarus include the release of jailed individuals based on political or religious beliefs, withdrawal of politically motivated legal charges against opposition activists and journalists, accounting for disappearances of opposition leaders and journalists, cessation of harassment against independent media and political opposition, prosecution of government officials responsible for fraudulent elections, and accounting for embezzlement of state assets. The proposed sanctions against the government of Belarus include prosecuting senior officials responsible for fraudulent elections, accounting for embezzlement of state assets, and holding free and fair elections under international supervision. Additionally, the President may deny entry into the US for senior Belarusian government officials and their immediate family members. The President can use section 212(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act to deny entry into the US for Belarusian officials, their family members, or individuals benefiting financially from actions undermining democracy in Belarus.
